guide.title: Gentoo Linux ATi FAQ
guide.abstract: This FAQ should help users avoid some common installation and configuration issues related to DRI and xfree for ATI boards.

body.p: Almost every ATI board is supported by Xfree86, at least for the 2D accelerated features. The 3D support is provided either by the DRI project, which is already present inside XFree86, or by closed source drivers provided by ATI.

section.title: I have an All-In-Wonder/Vivo board. Are the multimedia features supported?

body.p: The multimedia features are actually supported by the GATOS project.
body.warn: ati-gatos is currently outdated. We are planning to add gatos support directly inside xfree.

section.title: I'm not using an x86. What are my options?

body.p: You have almost the same xfree support on ppc or alpha platform but you can't use the ATI closed source drivers. That means that you can't use the r300 3d features at all. If you have such a board and you want it supported by xfree, you should contact ATI and ask them to open the specs.

section.title: I have a laptop. Is my "mobility" ATI model supported?

body.p: It should be but you may have a configuration issue due to the OEM PCI id that such chips may have. In most cases you may have to write the configuration file yourself or use the xf86config.
The xfree ebuild provides XFree86. xfree-drm provides the kernel modules required by DRI and ati-drivers provides the ATI closed source X drivers and kernel modules.
body.impo: Your kernel must have agpgart support and not have the DRM modules compiled in.
body.pre:
If you want just the Rage128 drivers and modules installed with xfree
# VIDEO_CARDS="rage128" emerge xfree-drm To have just the Radeon support (r100, r200, r250, but not r300 yet) # VIDEO_CARDS="radeon" emerge xfree-drm To install the ATI closed source drivers (r200,r250 and r300 only) # emerge ati-drivers To install just XFree86 but not install any kernel module # emerge xfree

body.p:
It is suggested the use of xf86cfg, xf86config or directly by using the XFree86 auto configuration option:
# X -configure
For more information on how to get a basic XF86Config configuration file, please refer to the Desktop Configuration Guide.
body.note: Users of the ati-drivers can also use fglrxconfig.
body.impo: PPC users should use the Xeasyconf stand alone configurator by emerging the xeasyconf ebuild.
